channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Suicide Bomber Strikes at Ahmadi Mosque in Bangladesh
item.description: The bomber was the only person killed in the explosion, which wounded three worshipers in the mosque, in a remote northern village.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK

item.title: U.S. Foreign Arms Deals Increased Nearly $10 Billion in 2014
item.description: American weapons sales to other countries rose to $36.2 billion last year, more than half of the global arms trade, a congressional study found.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS FANDOS
item.media:credit: Yonhap, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A United States-South Korea joint military exercise in Yeoncheon, northeast of Seoul. South Korea, a key American ally, was the world’s top weapons buyer in 2014, completing $7.8 billion in contracts.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Telling South Sudan’s Tales in a Language Not Its Own
item.description: Stella Gaitano has built a distinguished literary reputation for her writings about conflict and displacement, and she has done so in Arabic, the tongue of the north.
item.dc:creator: ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: The writer Stella Gaitano in Juba, South Sudan, last year.

item.title: Powerful Syrian Rebel Leader Reported Killed in Airstrike
item.description: The death of the leader, Zahran Alloush, who commanded the Army of Islam, is a significant blow to the armed opposition in the Syria conflict.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Narendra Modi of India Meets With Pakistani Premier During Surprise Visit
item.description: Mr. Modi met with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif amid tentative steps by both nations to improve their historically tense relations.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:credit: Indian Press Information Bureau, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi was welcomed by the Prime Minister of Pakistan, Nawaz Sharif, at the airport in Lahore on Friday.

item.title: Chinese Official Vows Punishment Over Shenzhen Landslide
item.description: The city’s Communist Party chief offered an unusual apology for a construction collapse that toppled 33 buildings.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Gas Tanker in Nigeria Explodes, Killing Dozens
item.description: The blast occurred as people gathered to buy cooking gas to prepare Christmas meals. The president said “tens of people” were killed, but reporters said the toll was much higher.
item.dc:creator: TONY IYARE and AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Pope Calls in Christmas Message for Unity Against Militant Atrocities
item.description: Pope Francis urged the world in his Christmas message on Friday to unite to end atrocities by Islamist militants that he said were causing immense suffering in many countries.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.media:description: Pope Francis delivered his Christmas message from the central balcony of St. Peter's Basilica at the Vatican.

item.title: The China Factor | Part 6: China Plans a New Trade Route, but Partners Are Wary
item.description: Beijing’s effort to revive ancient trade routes is causing geopolitical strains, with countries like Turkey increasingly worried about becoming too dependent on China.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:credit: Fatih Akta/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A Russian warplane that was shot down by a Turkish fighter jet on Nov. 24. Turkey wanted to produce a missile system with China, in part to reduce its dependence on patrolling jet fighters.

item.title: Americans Held Hostage in Iran Win Compensation 36 Years Later
item.description: Buried in the omnibus spending bill signed into law last week are provisions to give each of the former hostages or their estates up to $4.4 million.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: One of the American hostages was shown to a crowd outside the United States Embassy in Tehran in November 1979.

item.title: World Briefing: Spain: A Change in Fortunes for African Migrants
item.description: About 35 migrants are among the top prize winners of Spain’s Christmas lottery, according to the owner of a lottery agency.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Indonesia: Boat Disaster’s Toll Rises
item.description: Rescuers on Thursday recovered 40 bodies from waters in central Indonesia, raising the confirmed death toll from the weekend sinking of a passenger boat to 63.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Japan: Court Paves Way for Utility to Restart 2 More Nuclear Reactors
item.description: The court lifted an April injunction that was filed by residents who said that an earthquake exceeding the reactors’ quake resistance could cause a disaster similar to the crisis set off by a March 2011 quake and tsunami.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Germany: After a Tearful Moment, a Girl’s Permit to Stay Is Extended
item.description: The girl, a 14-year-old Palestinian, began to cry during a televised forum in July when Chancellor Angela Merkel told her that Germany could not admit everyone who wanted to live in the country.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Cyprus: A Holiday Wish for Peace in 2 Languages
item.description: For the first time, the Greek and Turkish Cypriot leaders of the ethnically divided Mediterranean island took to the airwaves together to send out holiday wishes in both Greek and Turkish.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Arab League Condemns Abduction of Qataris by Armed Group in Iraq
item.description: At least 26 hunters, including senior members of Qatar’s royalty, were taken captive last week in southern Iraq, near the Saudi Arabian border.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Peggy Say, Voice for Hostages in Lebanon, Dies at 74
item.description: Ms. Say waged a nearly seven-year campaign to draw attention to a hostage situation in Lebanon, where her brother was held for nearly seven years.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS
item.media:credit: William Foley/The LIFE Images Collection, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Peggy Say hugged her brother Terry A. Anderson in 1992. Ms. Say lobbied for several years for the United States to orchestrate the release of Mr. Anderson, who was held hostage in Lebanon.

item.title: Fernande Grudet, ‘Madame Claude’ Who Ran High-Society Call-Girl Ring, Dies at 92
item.description: In her heyday, Madame Claude presided over 500 women she called her swans; she claimed her clients included John F. Kennedy and the shah of Iran.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM GRIMES
item.media:description: Fernande Grudet, better known as Madame Claude, in Paris before appearing on a television talk show in 1986.

item.title: Security Experts and Officials Diverge on ISIS as Hacking Threat
item.description: Officials wonder aloud if public infrastructure could be digitally disabled, but researchers say ISIS is not nearly so sophisticated, or inclined.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: NICOLE PERLROTH
item.media:description: George Osborne, Britain's chancellor of the Exchequer, says ISIS is trying to develop the ability to digitally disable public infrastructure. Others are less convinced.

item.title: A Puerto Rican Utility Makes Progress Toward a Debt Deal
item.description: The involvement of two bond insurers signaled that Prepa had found a way to satisfy its bondholders, who expect to be paid about $177 million on Jan. 1, without having to part with that much cash itself.
item.dc:creator: MARY WILLIAMS WALSH
item.media:credit: Dennis M. Rivera-Pichardo for The New York Times
item.media:description: A work site of the Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority. The utility is responsible for about $9 billion of Puerto Rico’s debt.
